author: NewUserHa
text:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No



VS Code Version: 1.81.0
OS Version: win10 1803

Steps to Reproduce:



package main

import (
	"fmt"
)

func main() {
	println("1")
	fmt.Println("2")
	println("3")
}


click "run and debug", returning

1
3
2

The output is randomly ordered. this happens for both the "output" and "debug console" panels and other languages, but not for the terminal which seems because it is just returning whatever the shell return.
Of course, cmd.exe doesn't have this issue at all, so this issue cost me some time to dig out why.
note: because both the "output" and "debug console" need whatever extension to write, the "Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: " question is left as it is.

author: VSCodeTriageBot
text:
Thanks for creating this issue! It looks like you may be using an old version of VS Code, the latest stable release is 1.81.1. Please try upgrading to the latest version and checking whether this issue remains.
Happy Coding!

author: Sockemboffer
text:
Type: Bug
I'm not sure if it's a configuration issue but the box selection commands Shift+UpArrow and the other directions are only selecting one character at a time using left and right and then whole lines moving up and down.
According to this page https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/codebasics in section "Column (box) selection" the behavior I was expecting seems correct for box selection. Those commands are issued using Ctrl+Shift+Alt+Down, up, left, etc. Even with those keys I was hoping there'd be a way to select words at a time with each left and right arrow but I could deal with a character at a time going left and right I suppose.
I wouldn't call this a bug (I suspect user error and or configuration) but there wasn't a sort of general documentation/confusion about instructions option.

author: BMBurstein
text:
I would like to be able to set VSCode to be the default git editor, but only when using the integrated terminal.
I develop remotely using the remote-ssh plugin. The remote machine does not have vscode (it is a headless server with no gui). I work on it using both vscode and the integrated terminal, as well as direct ssh.
When in the integrated terminal, I can open a file in vscode using code <file>. This command does not work in a direct ssh session. I would like to be able to set code as my default git editor (for example, for doing interactive rebases) when it is available, i.e. when using the integrated terminal.

author: VSCodeTriageBot
text:
Obrigado por criar esta edição!
No entanto, como a descrição não está em inglês, é difícil para nós trabalhar nela. Se você puder, edite esta edição para estar em inglês. Por favor, não adicione um novo comentário ou crie um novo problema, mas edite o problema existente.
Infelizmente, os serviços de tradução automática não são capazes de lidar com a linguagem técnica necessária para comunicar eficazmente sobre problemas de software, por isso recomendamos encontrar um tradutor humano que esteja familiarizado com a nossa tecnologia para ajudar a traduzir.
Caso contrário, esse problema foi marcado como necessitando de tradução e um membro da comunidade pode ajudar a traduzi-lo.

Thanks for creating this issue!
Unfortunately, as the description is not in English, it's hard for us to work on. If possible, please edit the original issue to be in English.
In our experience, automatic translation services are not able to handle the technical language needed to effectively communicate about software issues, so we recommend finding a human translator who is familiar with our technology to help.
Otherwise, we have marked this as needing translation and a community member may be able to help out.

author: florianhumblot
text:
When using CTRL+O or @symbol in VSCode you get the symbol names in the current document from the LSP. If you're using a language that supports function overloading like C++ or C# it can get really hard to navigate the file using that functionality.
It would be great to be able to see a function signature (or at the very least the function arguments) in this view so that you can navigate by typing the name + some part of the type.
An example of how this looks with a language server that handles the symbol names according to the spec:

compared to how it can look if you don't 100% follow the LSP spec:

The Microsoft C++ extension already supports this by including the details in the name field of the LSP but this means that every other LSP also would need to break the spec to support this feature (and other editors would then get unexpected information in the name field).
It would be nice to either by default show the function signature information by default in languages that support overloading, or to have an option that gets VSCode to show the function signature.
Discussion on the clangd patch that I made: https://reviews.llvm.org/D157080
Related issue in the clangd repo: clangd/clangd#1344
A (potentially incomplete) list of languages that support overloading: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_overloading

author: byehack
text:
I disabled editor.dragAndDrop, bcz it's annoying when I'm trying to select part of text inside of already selected text.
Also I need this feature, so I won't Copy/Paste or ALT+Down/Up most of time I'm trying move pieces of code.
As mouse customizable are not ready yet, My suggestion is ALT+DnD should be available as secondary option for who disabled editor.dragAndDrop.

author: neeleshb
text:
Type: Bug
The header row containing the menubar and banner has the role "contentinfo" which is incorrect because the "contentinfo" role is reserved only for the footer.  The role should be removed (changed to none / presentation).
VS Code version: Code 1.78.0 (252e546, 2023-05-03T20:09:46.685Z)
OS version: Linux x64 6.3.11-1rodete1-amd64
Modes:
Sandboxed: No

author: VSCodeTriageBot
text:
Thanks for creating this issue! It looks like you may be using an old version of VS Code, the latest stable release is 1.81.1. Please try upgrading to the latest version and checking whether this issue remains.
Happy Coding!

author: af4jm
text:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No VS Code Version: OS Version: Steps to Reproduce: I have a block of HTML in a Markdown file (using elements that don't have MD equivalents), a sample that represents the issue is...
Jackson Motorplex [![Google Maps](/icons/google_maps.png)](https://www.google.com/maps/@?api=1&map_action=map&basemap=satellite¢er=43.6275351,-94.9760521)
In the Markdown preview, ¢er is incorrectly rendered as ¢er, that rendering should only happen if the html were ¢er HTML escape sequences that do not end with ; should be ignored, especially when there are other alphabetic characters immediately following I notice the same issue in FireFox with a local html file, so it is likely an issue in a dependency, not in VSCode itself. In both cases (VSCode & FF), this escaping was not happening a few days ago.

author: dimension-zero
text:
I have a Python project that calls logging.error() frequently.  I'd like to be able to set (or un-set) a break-point on these calls all at once.
Find in Files lets me find the calls but then I have to set a breakpoint manually on each one.
This is very laborious and strikes me as a nice opportunity for automation.
It would be great to be able to automate batch setting (or unsetting) of breakpoints based on a search-pattern.
